ygData.subject: rtNeat and timeseries

Subject: rtNeat and timeseries
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=302211244; y=OAPTsryjNeS89vMCDk1_PLQELu0y2b1byywBfoT1FhgAOGpJSeo

Hi everyone,

I have been trying to evolve networks using rtNEAT which will learn a  
given target given the inputs, the target being a real number and the  
inputs are timeseries.  Now I know that there exists a neural net which  
can do this to a high degree of accuracy ( > 95% ) but cannot reproduce  
the results using rtNeat ( the C++ version) and wondered if I was doing  
something silly or if it simply cannot evolve a net to learn it.

Here is more information on my scenario:

Inputs : {i1,i2,i3,...,iN}, all of which are real numbers
Target Output : T, which is a real number value between 0 and 1

Here is the start genome:

genomestart 1
trait 1 0.1 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
trait 2 0.2 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
trait 3 0.3 0 0 0 0 0 0 0
node 1 0 1 1
node 2 0 1 1
node 3 0 0 2
gene 1 1 3 0.0 0 1 0 1
gene 2 2 3 0.0 0 2 0 1
gene 3 3 3 0.0 0 2 0 1
genomeend 1

and here are my parameters:

trait_param_mut_prob 0.5
trait_mutation_power 1.0
linktrait_mut_sig 1.0
nodetrait_mut_sig 0.5
weigh_mut_power 2.5
recur_prob 0.00
disjoint_coeff 1.0
excess_coeff 1.0
mutdiff_coeff 0.4
compat_thresh 3.0
age_significance 1.0
survival_thresh 0.20
mutate_only_prob 0.25
mutate_random_trait_prob 0.1
mutate_link_trait_prob 0.1
mutate_node_trait_prob 0.1
mutate_link_weights_prob 0.9
mutate_toggle_enable_prob 0.00
mutate_gene_reenable_prob 0.000
mutate_add_node_prob 0.03
mutate_add_link_prob 0.05
interspecies_mate_rate 0.001
mate_multipoint_prob 0.6
mate_multipoint_avg_prob 0.4
mate_singlepoint_prob 0.0
mate_only_prob 0.2
recur_only_prob 0.0
pop_size 100
dropoff_age 15
newlink_tries 20
print_every 30
babies_stolen 0
num_runs 15

The fitness function is simply to minimise the difference between the  
output and target values.  A winner is declared when a network has at  
least 80% accuracy.

Unfortunately despite running numerous attempts with varying amounts of  
runs, population sizes, and other parameters it still struggles to get  
consistently above 60%.   I know the structure required is a recurrent  
network with one hidden layer and it seems to get that far and the best it  
can achieve is 76% so far.  Could it be that the best networks are being  
destroyed through too higher mutation / crossover?  Is it that I need a  
diferent fitness function, if so what kind should i be using (i.e. should  
I be separating the outputs into wider ranges rather than approximate  
values) ?

Can anyone make any suggestions as to how to make it find better networks?

Many thanks in advance for any advice,

Tom
